The objections to these expedients are to my mind conclusive. (1) It does not follow, because to show the heinousness of hate it may be repre- sented as virtually equivalent to the murder of which it is the germ, that it is therefore allowable in all cases to substitute the word ‘ murder ' for ‘ hate.’ Iu the present case it may be safely said that no sane writer, no 0110 who had the slightest feeling for rhetorical effect (and St. James is both eminently sane and einiuently rhetorical) could have used φονεύετε 111 the sense of μισεῖτε before ζηλοῦτε. There is no reason here to lay an exaggerated stress on the idea of hate, if nothing more than hate is intended : not only does it make a mere bathos of ζηλοῦτε, but it weakens the force of the following μάχεσθε καὶ πολεμεῖτε. Others have thought it impossible that those addressed by St. James could be guilty of the actual sin of murder.
